Tech demand higher than output? Hardly. If that were the case than tech firms wouldn't be innudated with hundreds, sometimes thousands of resumes, even for entry level positions. Top talent wouldn't see their resume submissions go without response. US schools are full of US citizens studying STEM subjects, and that's not even including those trained through other venues such as the military or self-taught.

Go look at the Cornell or UC Berkeley salary surveys and post-graduation surveys. They can't even prove more than 1/3rd of their graduating classes have found employment, and those are top tier schools.

I would like to point out that Tim Tebow did some remarkable things as a rookie NFL quarterback. That pill over the Steeler cornerback on the first play of overtime in last's season's playoffs that went to the house for the win....you don't see that very often. Perfect read, perfect pass.

Tebow's intangibles dominate Sanchez. He is a natural leader, he is a physical baller, he is a very big man, and he doesn't get enough credit for his reads. Tebow often knows exactly where to go with the ball. He tends to be overly cautious instead of sticking it in there, and some of his balls just plain miss, but if you've been watching our quarterback play this season, we've already got ourselves one of those. For those of you looking for a reason not to insert Tebow, accuracy is not your strongest claim. Sanchez is near the bottom of the league in accuracy.

Tebow deserves to run the first team offense, the full package, with some option plays thrown in to take advantage of his agility. He can also pitch, then block. I'm not afraid of Tebow getting hurt if he's the one moving forward. He's a big man.

If Sanchez' desultory play has not earned him a trip to the bench, then what would? The Jets beat Miami almost in spite of Sanchez, and he was certainly the chief culprit in the 49ers blowout. Yes the defense missed tackles and so on, but most of that damage came in the second half when they were dog tired because the inept offense couldn't keep them off the field.

I say it is Tebow Time.

Mel, I think you have some excellent ideas.  My family and I hadn't heard about a suspected link between anesthesia and possible permanent damage to the brains of the elderly until after our mother had a mastectomy at age 87.  Though she had already been showing signs of dementia, she emerged from surgery much, much worse and has stayed that way (it has been over a year now.)  Delusions, which she hadn't had before, immediately became a huge problem and despite treatment have not abated.  We really wish that the surgeon had mentioned that this was a possible outcome, we could have put off the surgery until the cancer was a clear danger to her life.  Yes, the cancer is gone, but the person she was is gone, too.

My 78 year old father entered Tufts Medical Center and within one week, without any previous dementia history, was diagnosed with delirium.  His resulting bad behavior caused him to be ineligible for rehab which could have given him the physical therapy and normalcy he needed and may have permitted him one last visit home. He did well in Tufts'  ICU but I am convinced that the seriously dreary, loud lightless room and monotony in the main hospital caused the delirium.  What followed was a nightmare cycle of sedation, agitation, restraints and constant exhausting care by his family with no relief from staff who seemed overwhelmed/desensitized to the delirium which they  told us was unavoidable.  The revolving two week shift of young doctors did not help his care.  The hospital also opted for sedating my father over granting our exhausted family a sitter to watch him, to help wean him from the drugs, provide him company/reality and to give our family a day's rest.    That denial of a sitter (because they are more expensive than sedatives or antipsychotic drugs) resulted in my father falling in his delirious state.  My dear father lost dignity and underwent enormous and perhaps needless stress shortly before his death weeks later.  Those awful days will forever be burned in our memory.  Concerted effort should be made to expose patients to light/night,  to refrain from caffeinated beverages (duh!!), to have activity during daytime, and to have sitters (!!!!!!) instead of drugs.

In my experience as a practicing emergency room physician, I have found that the problems of alcohol abuse dwarf those of any other drug, legal or not, and possibly exceed the problems caused by the sum total of all other drugs combined. Mouse is totally correct in this respect. But I'm not sure why Mouse is setting up a moral dichotomy here -- the article and the responses do not refer to the moral superiority of one drug over another.

Insofar as the difference between someone drinking two glasses of wine versus someone taking two Percocets (a brand-name for a pill containing the prescription opiate oxycodone), Mouse is also right -- there is probably not much difference.

We are, however, talking about much more serious problems than this -- daily, excessive use, leading to serious work, family, health and legal problems. Whether the drug causing this is legal -- alcohol, prescription -- oxycodone, or illegal -- methamphetamine is beside the point.

Mr J acknowledged he was addicted.  Dr C appeared to offer an enlightened and compassionate response.  Is it a surprise that Mr J declined the offer?  No, this is what some addicts do. The work of Prochaska and Declimente  nearly 25 years ago highlighted the Transtheoertical model and stages of change.  Many will dwell at pre-contemplatve and contemplative stages. Their current physical and psychic pain in maintaining the status quo is preferable to the pain of embracing change.  And what can health care workers do but respect an individual's freedom to make his/her choices, as poor as sometimes they are. What's troubling here is the assertion that involuntary commitment of addicts  will somehow efficiently  resolve the dilemma.  If that were the case, wouldn't the doctor have to consider commiting  the diabetic who is in shock  with uncontrolled blood sugars, the 400  pound person with an eating disorder who fell and broke his hip and now needs a hip replacement,  the cardiac patient who has not lowered her lipid profile or  followed  the exercise plan from cardiac rehab and is now having another coronary?  At  one time before deinstitutionalization,  some aicoholics were locked away and told they were mentally ill, insane, and morally unfit. For the most part, they were none of these, but  persons with an addiction which the health systems of that era were incompetent to treat.  And the same theme continues today wiith fragmented, disjointed primary care and behav health?

Scientist, Candidate and Planet Earth’s Lifeguard

Jane Smiley got it. So many got it.

We got it.

But will our decisions matter?

To be radical and peaceful is to be wise.

Barry Commoner was wise, and his wisdom will grow in importance and relevance, sadly, as his message becomes more and more acute.

There are few like him.

We must treasure those with a willingness to differ.

They are needed now, more than ever.

Sandy Lewis

Thank you Barry, for leading a principled life and bringing those principles to the public stage.

There are many battles to be fought but the world always needs heroes. You will always be a hero
I'm afraid it's true. Your doctor may very well decline to see you once you're on Medicare, or he/she may require that you get a Medicare Advantage plan that reimburses better.

I don't recall the public paying for my medical tuition, nor taking care of me while toiling late into the night, skipping weekend parties and friends so I could study to become a doctor.  Doctors are not your servants, they are free people who also deserve to be treated humanely by both the society and their patients.  The physician patient relationship is a MUTUAL TRUST.  One way relationships are for masters and servants.  We have to feed our families: if you expect us to drop everything when you or your family really need us, don't call us servants or you will find we aren't going to be there for you.

typically yes. Medicare reimbursement rates are not very high as compared to private insurers. In fact, most practices attempt to balance the ratio of medicare to private insurance patients to keep their billings up - enough to cover overhead and salaries. I would not panic. Good medicine depends on informed patients and annual physicals and labs are going by the wayside unless there are specific indications for tests such as risk factors or past conditions previously documented. Choose a practice network that is integrated to keep care optimal and reduces needless duplication of testing.

Not sure you are predicting the future. it is the present. the goal of the health care act is to ensure a minimum level of care for all. it is the first step. Control of costs and a decrease in administrative paperwork is a battle the health care bill  as well as other proposals have failed to address and this will take lots of cooperation to take on. are you ready to help tell pharma, hospitals, etc. to reduce their costs?
